content.html:
Programming Portals

A terrific piece by Maggie Appleton that starts with a comparison of graphical user interfaces and command line tools‚Äîwhich reminds me of the trade-offs between seamless and seamful design‚Äîand then moves into a proposed paradigm for declarative design tools:

Small, scoped areas within a graphical interface that allow users to read and write simple programmes
content.value:
Programming Portals



A terrific piece by Maggie Appleton that starts with a comparison of graphical user interfaces and command line tools‚Äîwhich reminds me of the trade-offs between seamless and seamful design‚Äîand then moves into a proposed paradigm for declarative design tools:


  Small, scoped areas within a graphical interface that allow users to read and write simple programmes

content.html:
Speaking of in-person gatherings, I‚Äôve got some exciting‚Äîif not downright nervewracking‚Äîevents coming up soon.

Next week I‚Äôll be in London for Leading Design. Looking at the line-up that Rebecca is assembled, I‚Äôm kind of blown away‚Äîit looks fantastic!

You‚Äôll notice that I‚Äôm in that line-up, but don‚Äôt worry‚ÄîI‚Äôm not giving a talk. I‚Äôll be there as host. That means I get to introduce the speakers before they speak, and ask them a question or two afterwards.

Then, one week later, I do it all again at Clarity in New Orleans. I‚Äôm really honoured that Jina has invited me to MC. Again, it‚Äôs a ridiculously fantastic line-up (once you ignore my presence).

I really, really enjoy hosting events. And yet I always get quite anxious in the run-up. I think it‚Äôs because there isn‚Äôt much I can do to prepare.

During The Situation, I had something of an advantage when I was hosting UX Fest. The talks were pre-recorded, which meant that I could study them ahead of time. At a live event, I won‚Äôt have that luxury. Instead, I need to make sure that I pay close attention to each talk and try to come up with good questions.

Based on past experience, my anxiety is unwarranted. Once I‚Äôm actually talking to these super-smart people, the problem isn‚Äôt a lack of things to discuss, but the opposite‚Äîso much to talk about in so little time!

I keep trying to remind myself of that.

See, it‚Äôs different if I‚Äôm speaking at an event. Sure, I‚Äôll get nervous, but I can do something about it. I can prepare and practice to alleviate any anxiety. I feel like I have more control over the outcome when I‚Äôm giving a talk compared with hosting.

In fact, I do have a speaking gig on the horizon. I‚Äôll be giving a brand new talk at An Event Apart in San Francisco in December.

It was just a month ago when Jeffrey invited me to speak. Of course I jumped at the chance‚Äîit‚Äôs always an honour to be asked‚Äîbut I had some trepidation about preparing a whole new talk in time.

I‚Äôve mentioned this before but it takes me aaaaaaaages to put a talk together. Don‚Äôt get me wrong; I think it‚Äôs worth it. I may not be good at much, but I know I can deliver a really good conference talk ‚Ä¶once I‚Äôve spent ridiculously long preparing it.

But more recently I‚Äôve noticed that I‚Äôve managed to shorten this time period. Partly that‚Äôs because I recklessly agree to prepare the talk in a shorter amount of time‚Äînothing like a deadline to light a fire under my ass. But it‚Äôs also because a lot of the work is already done.

When I have a thought or an opinion about something, I write it down here on my own website. They‚Äôre brain farts, but their my brain farts. I consider them half-baked, semi-formed ideas.

For a conference talk, I need something fully-baked and well-formed. But I can take a whole bunch of those scrappy blog posts and use them as raw material.

There‚Äôs still a lot of work involved. As well as refining the message I want to get across, I have to structure these thoughts into a narrative thread that makes sense. That‚Äôs probably the hardest part of preparing a conference talk ‚Ä¶and the most rewarding.

So while I‚Äôve been feeling somewhat under the gun as I‚Äôve been preparing this new talk for An Event Apart, I‚Äôve also been feeling that the talk is just the culmination; a way of tying together some stuff I‚Äôve been writing about it here for the past year or two.

It‚Äôs still entirely possible that the talk could turn out to be crap, but I think the odds are in my favour. I‚Äôve been able to see how the ideas I‚Äôve been writing about have resonated with people, so I can feel pretty confident that they‚Äôll go down well in a talk.

As for the topic of the talk? All will be revealed.

As for the topic of the talk? All will be revealed.

content.html:
Get Blogging!

Your easy guide to starting a new blog.

A blog is an easy way to get started writing on the web. Your voice is important: it deserves its own site. The more people add their unique perspectives to the web, the more valuable it becomes.
content.value:
Get Blogging!




  Your easy guide to starting a new blog.
  
  A blog is an easy way to get started writing on the web. Your voice is important: it deserves its own site. The more people add their unique perspectives to the web, the more valuable it becomes.

content.html:
I‚Äôve had the opportunity to gather with my peers a few times over the past couple of months.

There was dConstruct, which I hosted. That was just lovely.

Then a few weeks ago, in spite of train strikes and travel snags, I went to Bristol to give a talk at Web Dev Conf, a really nice gathering.

This past weekend I was in London for State Of The Browser, this time as neither host nor speak, but as an attendee. It was really good!

I noticed something rather lovely. There was enough cross-over in the audiences for these events that I got to see some people more than once. That‚Äôs something that used to happen all the time but became very rare over the past two years because of The Situation.

None of the organisers of these events were pretending that Covid has gone away. Each event had different processes in place to mitigate risk. I wrote about the steps I took for dConstruct. For some people, those measures might seem to go too far. For other people, they don‚Äôt go far enough. This is a challenge that every in-person event is facing and from what I‚Äôve seen, they‚Äôre all doing their level best.

None of these events were particularly large. Attendence was maybe somewhere between 100 and 200 people at each one. I know that there‚Äôs still a risk in any kind of indoor gathering but these events feel safer than the really big tech gatherings (like the one in Berlin where I got the ‚Äôrona‚Äîthat was literally tens of thousands of people).

Anyway, all three events were thoroughly enjoyable. Partly that‚Äôs because the talks were good, but also because the socialising was really, really nice‚Äîall the nicer for being in relatively safe environments.

It‚Äôs not exactly an earth-shattering observation to point out that the social side of conferences is just as valuable as the content. But now that so many of us are working remotely, I feel like that aspect of in-person events has become even more important.

Or maybe I‚Äôm just appreciating that aspect of in-person events after spending such a long time with screen-mediated interactions only.

None of the organisers of these events were pretending that Covid has gone away. Each event had different processes in place to mitigate risk. I wrote about the steps I took for dConstruct. For some people, those measures might seem to go too far. For other people, they don‚Äôt go far enough. This is a challenge that every in-person event is facing and from what I‚Äôve seen, they‚Äôre all doing their level best.

None of these events were particularly large. Attendence was maybe somewhere between 100 and 200 people at each one. I know that there‚Äôs still a risk in any kind of indoor gathering but these events feel safer than the really big tech gatherings (like the one in Berlin where I got the ‚Äôrona‚Äîthat was literally tens of thousands of people).

Anyway, all three events were thoroughly enjoyable. Partly that‚Äôs because the talks were good, but also because the socialising was really, really nice‚Äîall the nicer for being in relatively safe environments.

It‚Äôs not exactly an earth-shattering observation to point out that the social side of conferences is just as valuable as the content. But now that so many of us are working remotely, I feel like that aspect of in-person events has become even more important.

Or maybe I‚Äôm just appreciating that aspect of in-person events after spending such a long time with screen-mediated interactions only.

content.html:
Why We‚Äôre Breaking Up with CSS-in-JS | Brad Frost

I‚Äôve seen the pendulum swing back and forth many times over my years building on the web. I too feel like there‚Äôs something in the air right now, and people are finally acknowledging that most single page apps are crap.

But Brad makes the interesting point that, because they were incubated when profligate client-side JavaScript was all the rage, web components may have ended up inheriting the wrong mindset:

So now the world of web components has egg on its face because the zeitgeist at the time of its design didn‚Äôt have such a strong focus on SSR/HTML-first/ progressive enhancement. Had web components been designed in the current zeitgeist, things would almost certainly be different.
content.value:

But Brad makes the interesting point that, because they were incubated when profligate client-side JavaScript was all the rage, web components may have ended up inheriting the wrong mindset:


  So now the world of web components has egg on its face because the zeitgeist at the time of its design didn‚Äôt have such a strong focus on SSR/HTML-first/ progressive enhancement. Had web components been designed in the current zeitgeist, things would almost certainly be different.

content.html:
A recurring theme in my writing and talks is ‚Äúlay off the JavaScript, people!‚Äù But I have to make a conscious effort to specify that I mean client-side JavaScript.

I thought it would be obvious from the context that I was talking about the copious amounts of JavaScript being shipped to end users to download, parse, and execute. But nothing‚Äôs ever really obvious. If I don‚Äôt explicitly say JavaScript in the browser, then someone inevitably thinks I‚Äôm having a go at JavaScript, the language.

I have absolutely nothing against JavaScript the language. Just like I have nothing against Python or Ruby or any other language that you might write with on your machine or your web server. But as soon as you deliver bytes over the wire, I start having opinions. It just so happens that JavaScript is the universal language for client-side coding so that‚Äôs why I call for restraint with JavaScript specifically.

There was a time when JavaScript only existed in web browsers. That changed with Node. Now it‚Äôs possible to write code for your web server and code for web browsers using the same language. Very handy!

But just because it‚Äôs the same language doesn‚Äôt mean you should treat it the same in both circumstance. As Remy puts it:

There are two JavaScripts.

One for the server - where you can go wild.

One for the client - that should be thoughtful and careful.

I was reading something recently that referred to Eleventy as a JavaScript library. It really brought me up short. I mean, on the one hand, yes, it‚Äôs a library of code and it‚Äôs written in JavaScript. It is absolutely technically correct to call it a JavaScript library.

But in my mind, a JavaScript library is something you ship to web browsers‚ÄîjQuery, React, Vue, and so on. Whereas Eleventy executes its code in order to generate HTML and that‚Äôs what gets sent to end users. Conceptually, it‚Äôs like the opposite of a JavaScript library. Eleventy does its work before any user requests a URL‚ÄîJavaScript libraries do their work after a user requests a URL.

To me it seems obvious that there should an entirely different mindset for writing code intended for a web browser. But nothing‚Äôs ever really obvious.

I remember when Node was getting really popular and npm came along as a way to manage all the bundles of code that people were assembling in their Node programmes. Makes total sense. But then I thought I heard about people using npm to do the same thing for client-side code. ‚ÄúThat can‚Äôt be right!‚Äù I thought. I must‚Äôve misunderstood. So I talked to someone from npm and explained how I must be misunderstanding something.

But it turned out that people really were treating client-side JavaScript no different than server-side JavaScript. People really were pulling in megabytes of other people‚Äôs code to ship to end users so that they could, I dunno, left pad numbers or something.

Listen, I don‚Äôt care what you get up to in the privacy of your own codebase. But don‚Äôt poison the well of the web with profligate client-side JavaScript.

I have absolutely nothing against JavaScript the language. Just like I have nothing against Python or Ruby or any other language that you might write with on your machine or your web server. But as soon as you deliver bytes over the wire, I start having opinions. It just so happens that JavaScript is the universal language for client-side coding so that‚Äôs why I call for restraint with JavaScript specifically.

But just because it‚Äôs the same language doesn‚Äôt mean you should treat it the same in both circumstance. As Remy puts it:

Whereas Eleventy executes its code in order to generate HTML and that‚Äôs what gets sent to end users. Conceptually, it‚Äôs like the opposite of a JavaScript library. Eleventy does its work before any user requests a URL‚ÄîJavaScript libraries do their work after a user requests a URL.

I remember when Node was getting really popular and npm came along as a way to manage all the bundles of code that people were assembling in their Node programmes. Makes total sense. But then I thought I heard about people using npm to do the same thing for client-side code. ‚ÄúThat can‚Äôt be right!‚Äù I thought. I must‚Äôve misunderstood. So I talked to someone from npm and explained how I must be misunderstanding something.

Listen, I don‚Äôt care what you get up to in the privacy of your own codebase. But don‚Äôt poison the well of the web with profligate client-side JavaScript.

content.html:
Why we need CSS Speech - Tink - L√©onie Watson

I was talking about this with L√©onie just yesterday. I, for one, would love to have CSS speech support. You know who else would love it? Content designers!

In these days of voice interaction on every platform, there is a growing expectation that it should be possible to design that experience just like we can the visual experience. In the same way an organisation chooses a logo and colour palette for its website, it stands to reason that they may also choose a particular voice that represents their brand.

It‚Äôs wild that there‚Äôs no way to do this on the web.
content.value:

In the same way an organisation chooses a logo and colour palette for its website, it stands to reason that they may also choose a particular voice that represents their brand.


It‚Äôs wild that there‚Äôs no way to do this on the web.
